The selective conversion of alkynes into bromotriazoles over a single-component catalyst is highly desirable but presents significant challenges. In this study, we developed a robust copper-bonded polyoxomolybdates-based framework [Cu2(Mo6O20)]·2H2O (CPF-1), and it integrates the catalytic ability of Cu(I) site with the multielectron-transfer ability of polyoxometalates. As a result, CPF-1 exhibits favorable bifunctional catalytic activity for click chemistry and achieves 99% yield in the conversion of corresponding products to bromotriazoles. To our knowledge, CPF-1 represents the first heterogeneous catalyst that significantly enhances cascade reaction with excellent efficiency and sustainable recyclability. Additionally, the possible cascade catalytic mechanisms of these two reactions are also proposed. Graphical abstract The copper-bonded polyoxomolybdates-based framework (CPF-1) exhibits highly efficient heterogeneous catalytic activities in tandem click and bromination reactions (yields of up to 99 %). Furthermore, CPF-1 can be easily recovered and reused without significant loss of activity after seven reaction cycles. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Polyoxometalates Bifunctional catalysis Click Bromination Heterogeneous Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Polyoxometalates (POMs) are widely recognized as an extensively studied class of discrete, anionic early transition-metal-oxygen nanoclusters with fascinating structural diversity and electronic versatility, which make them highly attractive for interdisciplinary applications in catalysis, adsorption, luminescence and medicine [1–7]. In the field of POMs, significant progress has been made in developing transition-metal-based POMs hybrids that exhibit exceptional catalytic activities and rapid reversible multi-electron redox conversions [8–11]. Notably, numerous intriguing polyoxomolybdates incorporating transition metals have been discovered [12,13]. For instance, Niu's group reported the effective catalytic performance of organophosphonate-functionalized 36-molybdate polyoxomolybdates in Knoevenagel condensation [14]. Recently, Amini and coworkers presented a novel copper-based polyoxomolybdates catalyst with high photocatalytic activity for azide-alkyne cycloaddition (AAC) under UV-light irradiation [15,16]. However, the utilization of low-cost copper-bonded polyoxomolybdates-based framework in tandem reactions is still relatively limited. Therefore, to further explore the cascade catalytic performance of POMs, there is a pressing need to design and synthesize functionalized copper-bonded polyoxomolybdates-based framework catalyst with sustainable recyclability [17–19]. The AAC reaction, a classical one-pot “click” transformation for the synthesis of triazole chemicals, is an effective organic conversion method that can be used for preparing various bioactive fine chemicals [20–24]. Bromination also serves as a powerful and straightforward strategy for synthesizing functionalized organic bromides [25,26]. Generally, both click reaction [27–32] and bromination reaction [33–35] are typically conducted in the presence of cooper salts. However, they often encounter challenges such as difficulties in catalyst recovery and high reaction temperature [36,37]. To our knowledge, there have been few reports on the utilization of copper-bonded polyoxomolybdates hybrids in cascade click reaction and their derivatization. Hence, it is highly desirable and long-awaited to develop a heterogeneous CPF catalyst that can promote cascade reactions to synthesize brominated triazole products. Herein, the copper-bonded polymolybdates-based framework [Cu2(Mo6O20)]·2H2O (CPF-1) was controllably synthesized and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography and so on. Furthermore, CPF-1 as an effective heterogeneous catalyst for the tandem click and bromination reaction was first disclosed in the field. The results revealed that CPF-1 exhibited highly efficient heterogeneous catalytic activities in both tandem click and bromination reactions, achieving yields up to 99 %. Moreover, it demonstrated excellent recyclability without significant loss of activity after seven consecutive runs. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of [Cu2(Mo6O20)]·2H2O (CPF-1) CPF-1 was prepared according to the previously reported method with minor modifications [38]. Cu(OAc)2·H2O (0.065 g, 0.30 mmol), 4,4′,4′'-methanetriyltris(2-hydroxybenzoic acid) (0.0470 g, 0.1 mmol), (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (1.56 g, 1.25 mmol) were dissolved in the distilled water (10 mL), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 3 h, and then the suspension was placed into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and kept under autogenous pressure at 160 °C for 5 days. After slowly cooling to room temperature, blue-green crystals were obtained (0.069 g, 43 % yield). IR (KBr, cm−1): 3426 (w), 3220 (w), 1590 (s), 1024 (s), 913 (s), 853 (s), 769 (s), 658 (s), 528 (s). 2.2 Typical procedure for the click and bromination reactions. Click reaction. Compound 1 (0.35 mmol), compound 2 (0.25 mmol), CPF-1 (2 mol %) and 2 mL methanol were placed in a 10 mL schlenk tube and stirred at 80 °C for 8 h. After the reaction was completed, the product was detected by GC-MS with C6H5Cl as an internal standard. Then the product was purified by flash chromatography over neutral alumina using petrol/ethyl acetate (20:1 to 10:1) as eluent. Bromination reaction. The mixture of compound 3 (0.25 mmol), NBS (0.5 mmol), CPF-1 (2 mol%) and 2 mL of acetonitrile was placed in a 10 mL schlenk tube and reacted at 120 °C for 18 h. After the reaction was completed, the product was detected by GC-MS with C6H5Cl as an internal standard. Then the product was purified by flash chromatography over neutral alumina using petrol/ethyl acetate (20:1 to 10:1) as eluent. 3 Results and discussion Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) analysis demonstrates that CPF-1 crystallizes in a centrosymmetric space group Pnma (Table S1) and belongs to the metal oxide framework built from Cu(I)-linked (Mo6O20) n chains. The asymmetric unit of CPF-1 contains a half-occupied Cu ion (Cu1), one full (Mo1) and a half-occupied (Mo2) Mo atoms, three full (O3, O6, and O7) and four half-occupied (O1, O2, O4, and O5) O atoms as well as a half-occupied lattice-water molecule (Fig. S1). The structure of CPF-1 is based on the building blocks {Mo3}, consisting of three MoO6 octahedra sharing edges, and the central atom is µ 3-O (O3) (Fig. 1 a). The building blocks {Mo3} are propagated along the b-axis through the µ 3-O bridges to form 1D polymolybdate chain with a composition of (Mo6O20) n (Fig. 1b). In the b-axis direction, the 1D chains are interconnected by Cu-O bonds (Cu1-O1 = 1.882 Å, Cu1-O2 = 1.906 Å, and Cu1-O6 = 2.199 Å) to form a 3D framework (Fig. 1c and Table S2). Among them, the seven O atoms can be divided into three kinds according to their binding fashion to Mo or/and Cu: µ-O (O7), µ 2-O (O1, O2, and O6), µ 3-O (O3, O4, and O5), where µ 3-O atoms bridge three Mo atoms including one Mo1 ion and two symmetry-related Mo2 ions (Fig. S2). From the topological viewpoint, the polymeric (Mo6O20) n chain can be dissected into face-fused saddle-like {Mo5O4} units that can be considered as a five-connected node (Fig. S2), and the Cu ions are regarded as a three-connected node, then the framework of CPF-1 can be simplified as a 2-nodal (3,5)-connected topology with the Schläfli symbol of {42.65.83}{42.6} (Fig. 1d). Of note, this structure represents a new member in the missing link between zeolites and polyoxometalates [39,40]. The PXRD peaks of the simulated and experimental pattern for CPF are matched well, which manifested the phase purities of CPF-1 (Fig. S3). Fig. S4 display the IR spectra of CPF-1, indicating the characteristic of this polyoxomolybdate, the characteristic bands at 913, 853 and 769 cm−1 for CPF-1, are attributed to v(Mo-Ot), v(Mo-Ob-Mo), v(Mo-Oc-Mo). These results further confirm the composition of CPF-1 [41]. In order to verify the catalytic properties of CPF, we initially chose phenylacetylene 1a and benzylazide 2 as the model benchmark substrates for optimizing reaction conditions. The optimized results are presented in Table S4. Initially, 0.35 mmol of 1a reacted with 0.25 mmol 2 without any catalyst resulting in a trace yield of triazole 3a (Table S4, Entry 1). To improve the yield of the desired product, CPF-1 was used as the catalyst which significantly increased the yield up to 99 % for product 3a (Table S4, Entry 2), and the corresponding yield is higher than those of the reported catalysts. For example, homogeneous catalysts CuI [22], CuCl2, and the mixture of (NH4)6Mo7O24 and Cu(OAc)2 could promote the reaction in 81-93 % yield, while the heterogeneous catalyst Cu(OTf)2(SNS)(H2O) could catalyse the reaction in 92 % yield [24] (Table S4, Entries 3-6). Next, the impact of catalyst loading on the yields was further examined by increasing the CPF-1 loading from blank to 2 mol %. As a result, there was a substantial improvement in product yields from 5 % to 99 % (Fig. 2 a). Nevertheless, no obvious increase in yield was observed beyond a catalyst loading of 2 mol %. Subsequently, various reaction temperatures ranging from 25 °C to 80 °C were investigated. This led to an enhancement in product yields from 6 % to 99 % (Fig. 2b). Furthermore, the effect of reaction time and solvent on the click reaction was sequentially tested (Fig. 2c and 2d). The investigation unveiled that MeOH demonstrated superior performance in comparison to other solvents such as DCM, MeCN and THF, leading to the formation of 3a in low yields at 80 °C for 8 h. Based on these results, the optimized conditions were established as follows: 0.35 mmol 1, 0.25 mmol 2, 2 mol % CPF-1 and 2 mL MeOH at 80 °C for 8 h. Next, we investigate the catalytic behaviours of the CPF-1 towards the cycloaddition of various functionalized phenylacetylenes with benzyl azide 2 under the optimal conditions. As shown in Table 2, phenylacetylenes with various electron-donating groups at the para-position (-Me, -Et, and -Pr) all smoothly underwent to afford desired products with yields ranging from 94 % to 96 % (Table 1 , 3b-3d). Phenylacetylene with electron-withdrawing groups such as –Cl was also tested. It is worth noting that the yield of 3e decreased to 66 % under identical conditions, which may be caused by the steric hindrance effect. Nevertheless, 1-chloro-4-ethynylbenzene could proceed the reaction smoothly and afford 3f in 97 % yield. Notably, monoalkynyl- and dialkynyl-substituted phenylacetylenes also underwent successfully the AAC reaction and gave the desired products with yields of 70 % and 65 %, respectively (Table 1, 3g-3h). To investigate the derivatization of click products, NBS was added to the click reaction system. To our delight, the desired brominated product was detected. Then the bromination conditions were optimized and summarized in Table S5 in the Supporting Information. Firstly, the reaction encountered difficulties in the absence of catalyst (Table S5, Entry 1). Similarly, CPF-1 exhibited higher catalytic activity compared to homogeneous Cu(NO3)2 in bromination reaction, achieving a yield of 99 % (Table S5, Entries 2, 4). Decreasing the amount of CPF-1 led to decrease in yield (Table S5, Entries 2-3). The NBS loading was further evaluated, and increasing the amount of NBS significantly improved the yield (Fig. 3 a). These results demonstrated that using 2 equiv. NBS effectively enhanced triazole bromination. Simultaneously, temperature and reaction time also influenced the yield of bromination. The optimal conditions were observed at 120 °C for 18 h (Fig. 3b and 3c). Furthermore, various solvents were also investigated and acetonitrile proved to be the best choice for the triazole bromination (Fig. 3d). Therefore, based on these findings, we determined that compound 3 (0.25 mmol) should be reacted with NBS (0.5 mmol), CPF-1 (2 mol %), acetonitrile (2 mL), at 120 °C for 18 h to achieve optimal yields. To verify the heterogeneous nature of the CPF-1 catalyst, the hot filtration experiment of CPF-1 in click and bromination reaction was then performed. As shown in Fig. 4 a, CPF-1 was removed after 2 h at 80 °C and the click reaction was conducted for an additional 6 h in the filtrate. A negligible yield of 3a was observed after filtration, indicating that CPF-1 catalyst exhibits heterogeneous performance in the click reaction. On the other hand, the leaching experiment of bromination was conducted under optimized conditions and the result demonstrated that the catalyst could be easily recovered by its heterogeneous nature (Fig. 4b). Additionally, the recoverability and stability of catalysts are crucial characteristics for the potential industrial applications. The recovered CPF-1 was collected by simple centrifugation and washed three times with ethanol. After undergoing seven consecutive cycles, the catalytic activities of CPF-1 remained consistent in both click reaction and bromination reaction (Fig. 4c and 4d). The IR spectra and PXRD patterns of the recovered CPF-1 were still in good agreement with the simulated sample (Fig. 5 a and 5b). It was also confirmed by analyzing the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of CPF-1 (Fig. 5c and 5d). These results collectively indicate that CPF-1 maintained its crystallinity and structural integrity during the catalytic cycle. With the optimized reaction conditions in hand, we investigated the reaction scope for synthesizing brominated products featuring various substituted moieties (Table 2 ). Triazoles bearing -Me, -Et and -Pr substituents at the para-position relative to phenylacetylene smoothly underwent conversion into the corresponding brominated products with yields of 95 %-97 % (4b-4d), respectively. Despite steric hindrance, catalyzed by CPF-1, the starting substrate was also successfully transformed into the corresponding brominated product with an 86 % yield (4e). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to investigate the mechanism of the AAC reaction and detailed discussion see Supporting Information (Fig. S5). According to the results obtained from DFT calculations, catalytic tests and previous literatures [42–46], a plausible click reaction mechanism catalyzed by CPF-1 was proposed and depicted in Scheme 1 . Initially, phenylacetylene 1a underwent a reaction with CPF-1 to form Cu(I)-alkyne intermediate A [42]. Subsequently, copper insertion into compound 2 led to the generation of Cu(III)-acetylide intermediate B [46,47]. The CN bond formation between the terminal nitrogen and alkynyl carbon of B resulted in the formation of an intermediate six-membered ring C [43]. Furthermore, reductive elimination occurred to form a 5-copper triazole intermediate D, with upon protonation yielded product 3a, and CPF-1 was recovered. Moreover, the plausible mechanism of the bromination reaction was proposed according to literatures. Firstly, the proton of 3a was substituted by copper of CPF-1 to give copper (I) 1,2,3-triazolide intermediate E [34,48,49]. The formation of E played a crucial role in facilitating bromination as it reacted with NBS in virtually quantitative yield [34]. Then, NBS acted as an electrophile providing Br+ that attacked E through electrophilic substitution yielding product 4a (Scheme 2 ) [48]. 4 Conclusions In summary, the hydrothermal strategy was employed to incorporate copper catalytic sites into the polymolybdate cluster, resulting in the construction of a robust framework based on Cu-bonded covalently polymolybdate. Notably, CPF-1 is reported as the first heterogeneous catalyst for the tandem click and bromination reactions with high efficiency (up to 99 % yield), stability and recyclability, which may have far-reaching impact on the study of tandem transformations catalyzed by heterogeneous catalysts. Furthermore, DFT calculations were conducted to investigate the catalytic mechanisms of azide-alkyne cycloaddition reaction and NBS bromination reaction. The finding presents a novel approach for utilizing copper-bonded polymolybdate framework with excellent catalytic performance in a green and sustainable catalytic cascade reaction and the results will significantly contribute to the further understanding and design of transmit-metal-bonded POMs in the cascade heterogeneous catalysis, and lead to a systematic development of catalysts for specific purposes. coredata.dc:description: The selective conversion of alkynes into bromotriazoles over a single-component catalyst is highly desirable but presents significant challenges. In this study, we developed a robust copper-bonded polyoxomolybdates-based framework [Cu2(Mo6O20)]·2H2O (CPF-1), and it integrates the catalytic ability of Cu(I) site with the multielectron-transfer ability of polyoxometalates. As a result, CPF-1 exhibits favorable bifunctional catalytic activity for click chemistry and achieves 99% yield in the conversion of corresponding products to bromotriazoles. To our knowledge, CPF-1 represents the first heterogeneous catalyst that significantly enhances cascade reaction with excellent efficiency and sustainable recyclability. Additionally, the possible cascade catalytic mechanisms of these two reactions are also proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Copper-bonded polyoxomolybdates-based framework as a heterogeneous catalyst for the cascade click reaction and bromination
